docs.lead_paragraph: HCC Insurance Holdings Inc. withdrew its unsolicited $156.2 million takeover offer for Centris Group Inc. yesterday, a few hours after Centris rejected the bid as ''grossly inadequate.'' HCC, a property and casualty insurance company, wanted to broaden its product line with the addition of Centris, which covers unexpected medical claims against employers that self-insure employees' health care. On Jan. 11, HCC offered $13.25 a share for the 11.8 million outstanding Centris shares, a 20 percent premium over their value at the time. The shares have since traded up, closing yesterday at $14.0625, up 25 cents.

headline.main: HCC INSURANCE CANCELS 'GROSSLY INADEQUATE' CENTRIS BID

docs.abstract: HCC Insurance Holdings Inc withdraws its unsolicited $156.2 million takeover bid for Centris Group Inc, a few hours after Centris rejects offer as 'grossly inadequate' (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Giuliani administration has trained its quality-of-life sights on the city's dogs with a bill that would increase fines for harboring dogs deemed to be dangerous, deny dogs any consideration for being provoked into barking or biting, and require the owners of pit bulls to obtain $100,000 in liability insurance before being granted a dog license. ''It's a serious piece of legislation for a serious problem,'' said Colleen Roche, the press secretary for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. ''If it can prevent children or other New Yorkers from being maimed, disfigured or killed, it will serve its purpose.''

headline.main: Giuliani Proposes Tough Law on 'Dangerous' Dogs, Angering Owners

docs.abstract: New York City Mayor Giuliani administration trains its quality-of-life sights on city's dogs with bill that would increase fines for harboring dogs deemed to be dangerous, deny dogs any consideration for being provoked into barking or biting, and require owners of pit bulls to obtain $100,000 in liability insurance before being granted dog license; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: After a two-year detour into government largess, Gov. George E. Pataki today returned to the conservative path of his early years, proposing a $72.66 billion state budget with substantial cuts in health care and education. He proposed eliminating programs aimed at expanding prekindergarten classes and lowering class sizes. Though the state is flush with money, with a surplus expected to top $2 billion, Mr. Pataki called for a spending increase of just 1.8 percent in the fiscal year that begins April 1. That follows a 13 percent increase in spending, in part on education and Medicaid, during the two previous years, which helped enhance the Governor's popularity and propel him to a second term last November.

headline.main: Pataki Presents A Tight Budget, Despite Surplus

docs.abstract: New York Gov George E Pataki, in annual budget address, returns to conservative path of his early years by proposing $72.66 billion state budget with substantial cuts in health care and education; freezes most areas of spending, with increases too small to keep up with inflation; calls for spending increase of only 1.8 percent in fiscal 1999; proposes deep cuts in Medicaid and tuition assistance for low-income college students; asks for sharp drop in welfare spending; backs away from 1997 agreement aimed at expanding kindergarten and prekindergarten classes and lowering class sizes; calls for increase of barely 1 percent in aid to schools, to $11.9 billion; proposes $120 million increase, to $580 million, in state support for child care programs for poor, including those trying to leave welfare; will dedicate $200 million to new job-training effort for welfare recipients; other budget initiatives discussed; he says plan chooses smarter government over bigger government; Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver is sharply critical; says budget is unacceptable; says it has less to do with New York than with Pataki's ambitions for national office; accuses Pataki of tailoring policies to appeal to conservative Republican primary voters in other states; criticisms of other state and New York City officials noted; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-14 U.S. Threatens Air Strikes To Prod Kosovo Settlement The Clinton Administration announced a far-reaching plan to end the violence in Kosovo, calling for NATO air strikes if the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, refuses to accept a settlement granting Kosovo autonomy. If ethnic Albanian separatists who have been fighting for independence resist the plan, NATO could impose a blockade on the coast of Albania to cut off the flow of arms to the guerrillas. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: Amid a swirl of court papers and bitter feelings, the future of the Smithers Alcoholism Treatment and Training Center, a Manhattan institution with a celebrity-studded patient roster, is in doubt. Adele Smithers, the widow of the center's founder, said yesterday that she wanted her family's name removed from the stately mansion on East 93d Street if the current stewards of the program, Continuum Health Partners and St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center, relocate the program to a wing of the hospital in midtown Manhattan.

headline.main: Clouds Over Future of an Alcoholism Treatment Center

docs.lead_paragraph: Staking out a position for liberal Democrats, Senator Edward M. Kennedy plans to criticize the work of a bipartisan Federal advisory commission that would give private health insurers a much bigger role in running Medicare. In a speech prepared for delivery on Thursday, Mr. Kennedy describes the commission's approach as ''the wrong prescription.''

headline.main: Kennedy Opens Attack on Plan by Chief of Medicare Panel

docs.abstract: Sen Edward M Kennedy, staking out position for liberal Democrats, will criticize work of bipartisan Federal advisory commission that would give private health insurers much bigger role in running Medicare; speech to be delivered on January 28 describes commission's proposal, under which Medicare would offer fixed amount of money to each beneficiary to purchase insurance from private health plan or from Govt, as wrong prescription (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. George E. Pataki said today that for the next five years, New York State should use 75 percent of its share of the national tobacco lawsuit settlement, or $1.5 billion, to help reduce state debt. Just days ago, his aides signaled that the Governor wanted to use some of the settlement to provide coverage for the rapidly growing number of people without health insurance, raising the hopes of health care advocates that Mr. Pataki planned a major initiative for the uninsured. But the Governor made it clear today that he had in mind a sum that would pay to cover only a small fraction of the more than 3 million New Yorkers who are uninsured.

headline.main: Pataki Wants Tobacco Cash To Ease Debt

docs.abstract: Gov George E Pataki says that for next five years New York State should use 75 percent of its share of national tobacco lawsuit settlement, or $1.5 billion, to help reduce state debt; says that in first five years of 25-year settlement, 25 percent, or about $100 million a year, will go to state's share of health care; health care advocates had hoped for more money for coverage of more than 3 million New Yorkers who are not insured and for anti-smoking programs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A Federal advisory commission inched toward a fragile consensus today on a plan to redesign Medicare as a marketplace in which the Government would compete with private insurers. But Democrats insisted that elderly people get coverage for prescription drugs, raising doubts about whether the plan would save money. No votes were taken. But it appeared that 8 Republicans were ready to join 3 Democrats in support of the basic framework proposed by Senator John B. Breaux, the Louisiana Democrat who is chairman of the 17-member commission.

headline.main: Commission Nears a Consensus on Redesigning Medicare

docs.abstract: Federal advisory commission inches toward fragile consensus on plan to redesign Medicare as marketplace in which Government would compete with private insurers; Democrats are insisting that elderly get coverage for prescription drugs, raising doubts over whether plan would save money (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: While there is no question that health insurance costs are rising at a frightening pace for small businesses in New York (front page, Jan. 19), the key cause is the health maintenance organizations' inability to control health care costs, not New York's community rating law.

headline.main: Workers' Health Care Is a Good Buy; Spread the Costs

docs.abstract: Letter from Diane Archer of Medicare Rights Center on Jan 19 report on steep hikes in health insurance costs for small business; contends a key cause is health maintenance organizations' inability to control health care costs, not New York's community rating law, which prevents insurers from discriminating against small groups in their pricing and products

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: You report (front page, Jan. 19) that many small employers can no longer afford the steep costs of health insurance for their employees. They are more and more likely either to offer no health insurance or to force their employees to pick up a greater portion of the tab.

headline.main: Workers' Health Care Is a Good Buy; Try Universal Coverage

docs.abstract: Peter G Hill comments on Jan 19 report that many small employers can no longer afford steep costs of health insurance for their employees; sees need for end to employer-sponsored health insurance, and adoption of universal health insurance
